person_832.name: James
person_832.description: Possibly the name of a servant and companion during Davy's travels around Italy and Austria in 1819.

person_834.name: GiovanniDall'Armi
person_834.description: Lithographer and naturalist, on June 13 1822 donated a treatise on acoustical facts, read to the Accademia de' Lincei in Rome in 1821 to the Royal Society. Born in Trento, Italy and died in Rome.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_098.name: JosephineDetela
person_098.description: The daughter of the landlord of the Laybach (Ljubljana) inn at which Davy stayed in 1827 and 1828. Davy nicknamed her 'Pepina'. In Consolations in Travel (1830) he portrayed her in idealised terms as his nurturing nurse.

person_850.name: JosefMatyáš
person_850.description: A Habsburg nobleman of Gorizia, in the Tyrol.

person_597.name: FrancescoFerrara
person_597.description: Italian geologist, active mainly in Sicily, and known especially for his vulcanology studies.

person_875.name: HenryKing
person_875.description: Sir. British Lieutenant-Governor of Heligoland 1815–1840. Dates untraced.

person_258.name: EdwardBligh
person_258.description: Styled Lord Clifton until 1831 when he became 5th Earl of Darnley.  styled as Lord Clifton, who accompanied Davy on his tour of Scandinavia in 1824. Links to Memoirs vol. 2, p. 193. FRS.

person_876.name: MrRobertson
person_876.description: Dates untraced. An innkeeper at Mandals, Norway during Davy's trip there in 1824 with Lord Clifton.

person_259.name: Charles-FrédéricReinhard
person_259.description: French diplomat who served under a number of regimes.

person_879.name: MrMark
person_879.description: Dates untraced. The English Vice Consul at Christiansand, Norway, where Davy visited in 1824.

person_118.name: George GordonByron
person_118.description: From 1798 6th Lord Byron. Famous poet who knew both Humphry and Jane Davy in London and Italy; he wrote a slightly risqué skit on their marriage in 1812. FRSL.

person_880.name: BenjaminBloomfield
person_880.description: Army officer and courtier; between 1823 and 1832, he was Minister-Plenipotentiary to Stockholm.

person_881.name: Joseph François OscarBernadotte
person_881.description: Oscar I of Sweden; between 1824 and 1833 served as Viceroy of Norway (Crown Prince). He was King of Sweden and Norway from 8 March 1844 until his death.

person_884.name: Joséphine Maximilienne EugénieNapoléone de Beauharnais
person_884.description: Josephine of Leuchtenberg was Queen of Sweden and Norway from 8 March 1844 to 8 July 1859; she married the future king of Sweden and Norway (Oscar I of Sweden) in 1823.

person_885.name: Joséphinede Beauharnais
person_885.description: The grandmother of Josephine of Leuchtenberg and the the first wife of Napoleon.

person_889.name: ChristianFrederik
person_889.description: The King of Norway in 1814, and, as Christian VIII, King of Denmark from 1839 to 1848.

person_886.name: MrNolan
person_886.description: Dates untraced, a merchant Davy met in Norway.

person_349.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
person_349.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

person_888.name: Hans ChristianØrsted
person_888.description: Danish physicist and chemist who won the Copley Medal in 1820 for his electro-chemical experiments and discoveries; he had become a professor at the University of Copenhagen in 1806.

person_890.name: CarolineAmalie of Augustenburg
person_890.description: Married Christian Frederik (Prince Christian) in 1815, as his second wife; she became Queen of Denmark in 1839 to 1848.

person_893.name: MargaretaKlopstock
person_893.description: Née Moller. Born into a wealthy merchant family in Hamburg, was a German writer whose letters to Samuel Richardson were famous. She married the German poet Klopstock, before dying in childbirth with her first child.

person_892.name: Johanna Elisabethvon Winthem
person_892.description: Second wife of the German poet Klopstock.

person_894.name: Konrad Danielvon Blücher-Altona
person_894.description: Danish count, army officer, and President of Altona.

person_169.name: Heinrich ChristianSchumacher
person_169.description: Founder and Directort of the Altona astronomical observatory. Davy met him during a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

person_168.name: Carl FriedrichGauss
person_168.description: Prominent Hanoverian mathematician who was Director of the observatory at Gottingen University. Davy met him during a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

person_167.name: HeinrichOlbers
person_167.description: Astronomer who worked in Bremen. He specialised in the detection of asteroids and propounded his eponymous paradox. Davy met him on a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

person_119.name: NapoleonBuonaparte
person_119.description: French general and, as First Consul, 1799-1804, and Emperor, 1804-1815, military dictator of France and the territories it occupied. Established the Volta prize for research electricity and provided Davy with a passport to collect it in Paris in 1813.

person_897.name: MarkCatesby
person_897.description: English naturalist who studied the flora and fauna of the New World.

person_898.name: Germaine deStaël
person_898.description: Commonly known as Madame de Staël; a woman of letters and political theorist.

person_1072.name: Sir Thomas DykeAcland
person_1072.description: a British politician and baronet. The Aclands were an old Devon family and successive generations of the family sat in the House of Commons for the county.

person_1073.name: Lydia ElizabethAcland
person_1073.description: née Lydia Elizabeth Hoare, she was the daughter of banker Henry Hoare and married Thomas Acland in 1808.

person_324.name: RogerBacon
person_324.description: Medieval English philosopher and Franciscan friar.

person_810.name: Alexander III
person_810.description: The Great, King of Macedon, from which he conquered much of the world known in Greek antiquity.

person_401.name: JuliusCaesar
person_401.description: Roman general and dictator who first landed an army in Britain. Assassinated to prevent him gaining total power in Rome.

person_908.name: WilliamStanhope
person_908.description: A British statesman and diplomat, who became Secretary of State for Ireland, which he lost in 1742 but regained in 1744.

person_909.name: SpencerCompton
person_909.description: A British Whig statesman, who became prime minister and died in office.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_078.name: JohnLocke
person_078.description: English philosopher and physician, widely regarded as one of the most influential of early Enlightenment thinkers. FRSL.

person_518.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
person_518.description: German polymath active as a mathematician, natural philosopher and diplomat. Developed calculus over which he fought a priority dispute with Newton. ForMemRSL.

person_910.name: Thomasde Ercildoun
person_910.description: Remembered as Thomas the Rhymer, a Scottish laird, prophet and poet.

person_912.name: GeorgeVilliers
person_912.description: An English courtier, statesman and patron of the arts and 1st Duke of Buckingham, who was stabbed to death by John Felton, a lieutenant in the English Army.

person_918.name: JohnPitt
person_918.description: 2nd Earl of Chatham and commander of the army at the unsuccessful Walcheren Campaign in 1809.

person_919.name: Attila
person_919.description: The ruler of the Huns from 434 until his death.

person_920.name: GengisKhan
person_920.description: The founder and first khan of the Mongol Empire.

person_924.name: RobertStewart
person_924.description: Marquess of Londonderry, known as Viscount Castlereagh from 1796 to 1822, FRS 1802.

person_204.name: JamesCook
person_204.description: Royal Navy officer who commanded HMS Endeavour in its voyage of 1768-1771 to observe the transit of Venus from Tahiti on 3 June 1769. Joseph Banks served as naturalist on board.  Cook later commanded two further voyages to the Pacific. FRSL.

person_240.name: ErasmusDarwin
person_240.description: Physician and natural philosopher who was member of the Lunar Society and friend of Priestley and Watt; also a correspondent with Beddoes. FRSL.

person_280.name: Elizabeth I
person_280.description: Queen of England and Ireland from 1558 to 1603.

person_425.name: AmbroseGodfrey-Hanckwitz
person_425.description: German-born British apothecary who worked as Boyle's assistant and later became a phosphorus manufacturer. FRSL.

person_101.name: Ambrosio
person_101.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_108.name: Onuphrio
person_108.description: Onuphiro is the name of a fictional character in the dialogues of Davy's Consolations in Travel. The anglicized version of the name is Humphry.

person_102.name: Philalethes
person_102.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_140.name: Socrates
person_140.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

person_122.name: The Unknown
person_122.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_164.name: JamesHall
person_164.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

person_123.name: Barnaba Niccolò Maria LuigiChiaramonti
person_123.description: Pope Pius VII, 1800-1823, held prisioner by Buonparte, 1809-1813. In February 1814 Davy and his party stayed in the same inn that Pius had used the week before on his way back to Rome.

person_031.name: JohnMilton
person_031.description: Milton was a poet and polemicist. He wrote the epic poem Paradise Lost.

person_115.name: Moses
person_115.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_851.name: Thomas Stamford BingleyRaffles
person_851.description: British colonial official who served as the governor of the Dutch East Indies between 1811 and 1816 and lieutenant-governor of Bencoolen between 1818 and 1824. Because he had opposed (or restricted) the slave trade in his colonial administration, he was refused burial inside a parish church, and his gravesite was lost until 1914.

person_929.name: WilliamBissett
person_929.description: Younger brother of Sophia Brownrigg; Bishop of Raphoe

person_681.name: WilliamRichardson
person_681.description: Irish cleric, geologist, agriculturist and pamphleteer. Davy stayed with him when investigating the Giant's Causeway in Country Antrim.

person_288.name: ThomasBernard
person_288.description: Philantropist and a founding member of the Royal Institution serving as an early Treasurer. Later influential in running the institution, especially its lecture programme.

person_347.name: ShuteBarrington
person_347.description: Bishop of Durham, 1791 until death. An early Proprietor of the Royal Institution who hosted Davy when he was in the North-East working on his safety lamp.

person_928.name: SophiaBrownrigg
person_928.description: Wife of Sir Robert Brownrigg (q.v.), Governor of Ceylon.

place_952.name: Bagni di Lucca
place_952.description: A group of about 25 villages in northern Tuscany, less than 30 kilometres from Lucca, famous for its hot springs and thermal baths.

place_1080.name: Florence
place_1080.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

place_530.name: Apennines
place_530.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

place_942.name: Bologna
place_942.description: A city in and the capital of the Emilia-Romagna region in Northern Italy, of which it is also its largest.

place_1005.name: Modena
place_1005.description: A city in the Emilia-Romagna region in Northern Italy.

place_1332.name: Secchia
place_1332.description: The Secchia is an Italian river. One of the main right bank tributaries of the Po, it flows through the Emilia-Romagna region in northern Italy.

place_848.name: Velino
place_848.description: A river in central Italy, a tributary of the Nera.

place_247.name: Alps
place_247.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

place_622.name: Verona
place_622.description: Verona is a city located on the Adige River in the north of Italy.

place_947.name: Mantua
place_947.description: A city surrounded by 3 artificial lakes in the northern Italian region of Lombardy.

place_1006.name: Roverbella
place_1006.description: A comune in the Province of Mantua in the Italian region Lombardy.

place_1333.name: Mincio
place_1333.description: a river in the Lombardy region of northern Italy. It is the main outlet of Lake Garda.

place_328.name: Tyrol
place_328.description: Tyrol is a historical region in the Alps located in northern Italy and western Austria.

place_426.name: Adige
place_426.description: The second-longest river in Italy, which rises in the province of South Tyrol, near the Italian border with Austria and Switzerland.

place_948.name: Ala
place_948.description: A comune in Trentino, north-eastern Italy.

place_607.name: Rovereto
place_607.description: Rovereto is a city in northern Italy located on the Adige River.

place_551.name: Lago di Garda
place_551.description: Lake Garda is the largest lake in Italy.

place_537.name: River Colne
place_537.description: The River Colne is a tributary of the River Thames.

place_192.name: Illyrian Alps
place_192.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

place_333.name: Bolzano
place_333.description: Bolzano is the capital city of the province of South Tyrol in northern Italy.

place_336.name: Brixen
place_336.description: Brixen is a town in South Tyrol, Italy.

place_329.name: Carinthia
place_329.description: Carinthia is the southernmost Austrian State.

place_330.name: Eisack River
place_330.description: The Eisack River flows through northern Italy and the Austrian Tyrol.

place_280.name: Sillian
place_280.description: Sillian is a town in the Austrian state of Tyrol, in the district of Lienz.

place_260.name: Drava River
place_260.description: The Drava is a river in central southern Europe and is the fifth longest tributary of the Danube.

place_327.name: Brunecker Turm
place_327.description: Brunecker Turm is a mountain in South Tyrol, Italy.

place_1046.name: Isel
place_1046.description: A river in East Tyrol, Austria.

place_1334.name: Heiligenblut
place_1334.description: Heiligenblut am Großglockner is a municipality in the district of Spittal an der Drau in Carinthia, Austria.

place_1049.name: Overdranberg
place_1049.description: Oberdrauburg, in the Austrian state of Carinthia.

place_1050.name: Greiffenburg
place_1050.description: In the Austrian state of Carinthia.

place_555.name: Graz
place_555.description: Graz is Austria's second largest city.

place_1051.name: Sachsenburg
place_1051.description: In the Austrian state of Carinthia.

place_1052.name: Möll
place_1052.description: A river in northwestern Carinthia in Austria, a left tributary of the Drava.

place_1335.name: River Ischl
place_1335.description: The Ischl is a short river that begins at the Seeklause on Lake Wolfgangsee in Strobl and flows into the Traun in Bad Ischl

place_774.name: Bad Ischl
place_774.description: Bad Ischl is a spa town in Austria. It lies in the southern part of Upper Austria, at the River Traun in the centre of the Salzkammergut region.

place_1053.name: Spittal an der Drau
place_1053.description: A town in the Austrian state of Carinthia.

place_598.name: Millstätter See
place_598.description: Lake Millstatt is a lake in Carinthia, Austria.

place_309.name: Villach
place_309.description: Villach is a city in the Austrian state of Carinthia.

place_1057.name: Loikel
place_1057.description: A mountain range near Villach, Austria, exact location untraced.

place_1058.name: Mount Craie
place_1058.description: A mountain near Villach, Austria, exact location untraced.

place_1059.name: Tarvisio
place_1059.description: The village of Tarvisio, Italy, formerly Tarvis, Duchy of Carinthia, Austria.

place_1056.name: Lake Ossiach
place_1056.description: A lake in the Austrian state of Carinthia.

place_256.name: Wurzen Pass
place_256.description: Wurzen Pass is a mountain pass in a col of the Karawanks Mountain range between the Austrian state of Carinthia and the the Slovenian Kranjska Gora. It is named after the town of Podkoren (Wurzen).

place_181.name: Carniola
place_181.description: The Alpine region whose capital was Laybach (now Ljubljana). In 1827, Carniola was a Duchy within the Austrian Kingdom of Illyria.

place_214.name: Sava River
place_214.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

place_1060.name: Pontebba
place_1060.description: A commune in Italy, near the Austrian border.

place_1061.name: Udine
place_1061.description: This was a province in the autonomous Friuli-Venezia Giulia region of Italy, bordering Austria and Slovenia.

place_342.name: Ratmansdorff
place_342.description: Also known as Radovljica. Radovljica is a town in the Upper Carnolia region of Slovenia, located on the banks of the Sava River.

place_339.name: Loibl Pass
place_339.description: The Loibl Pass is a high mountain pass that links Slovenia with Austria.

place_343.name: Triglav
place_343.description: Also known as Terglou. Triglav is the highest mountain in Slovenia, located in the Julian Alps.

place_344.name: Sava Dolinka
place_344.description: Also known as Krainer Sava. Sava Dolinka is the headwater of the Sava River in north-western Slovenia.

place_1062.name: Maria See
place_1062.description: A lake, probably Lake Bled, in the Julian Alps of the Upper Carniolan region of northwestern Slovenia.

place_1063.name: Domodossola
place_1063.description: A city and comune in the region of Piedmont, northern Italy.

place_428.name: Postojna
place_428.description: A town in the traditional region of Inner Carniola, 35 km from Trieste, in south-western Slovenia.

place_1064.name: Planina
place_1064.description: A village in the Inner Carniola region of Slovenia.

place_1065.name: Großglockner
place_1065.description: The highest mountain peak in the Carinthian chain of mountains, in Carinthia, a southern province of Austria.

place_216.name: Ljubljana
place_216.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

place_1066.name: Kranj
place_1066.description: A city in Slovenia; the German name for the city was Krainburg.

place_1067.name: Kokra
place_1067.description: A river that converges with the Sava in Kranj, a city in Slovenia.

place_589.name: Vipava River
place_589.description: The Vipava is a river that flows through western Slovenia and north-eastern Italy.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_1071.name: Urking-See
place_1071.description: A river near Planina, a village in the Inner Carniola region of Slovenia; named untraced.

place_1072.name: Götzens
place_1072.description: A community in North Tyrol, Austria.

place_1076.name: Sucile
place_1076.description: Place, untraced, but somewhere on Davy's route between Götzens and Padua.

place_1075.name: Padua
place_1075.description: A province and a city in italy, west of Venice.

place_1079.name: Rovigo
place_1079.description: A city and comune in the Veneto region of Northeast Italy.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_1088.name: Greenwich
place_1088.description: In south-east london, on the banks of the River Thames, it is a famous maritime site.

place_1090.name: Coast of the Netherlands
place_1090.description: Davy sights part of the coast during his voyage from the Suffolk coast to Heligoland (islands in the North Sea).

place_1091.name: Dunes of Texel
place_1091.description: Described by Davy as the sand dunes of Tixel; he sees these as he makes his way to Heligoland.

place_1048.name: Heligoland
place_1048.description: A small chain of islands in the North Sea.

place_1092.name: Rleve, Norway
place_1092.description: Exact location untraced, but described as near Mandal, Norway.

place_349.name: Mandal, Norway
place_349.description: Mandal is a town in Vest-Agder county, Norway, which Davy visited in 1824.

place_350.name: River Tweed
place_350.description: One of the greatest salmon rivers in the UK; it flows east across the Border region in Scotland and northern England.

place_351.name: River Teviot
place_351.description: The largest tributary of the River Tweed by catchment area and a very important river for Atlantic salmon.

place_352.name: Mandal River
place_352.description: The river Mandalselva. Mandal is a town in Vest-Agder county, Norway.

place_106.name: Lakes of Killarney
place_106.description: Three lakes (Lough Leane, Muckross Lake - also called Middle Lake, and Upper Lake) surrounded by the MacGillycuddy's Reeks and now part of Killarney National Park.

place_156.name: Naples
place_156.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

place_354.name: Kristiansand
place_354.description: A city on the sea in Norway.

place_353.name: Torridal
place_353.description: A valley in Agder County, Norway.

place_355.name: Rhone River
place_355.description: A major river in France and Switzerland.

place_356.name: Lyon
place_356.description: Lyon is the third-largest city in France. It is located at the confluence of the Rivers Rhône and Saône, to the north-west of the French Alps.

place_570.name: Hamburg
place_570.description: Hamburg is one of Germany's three city-states alongside Berlin and Bremen, and is surrounded by Schleswig-Holstein to the north and Lower Saxony to the south.

place_266.name: Rhine
place_266.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

place_357.name: Arendal
place_357.description: A town or district in Agder County in south-eastern Norway.

place_1097.name: The Grampians
place_1097.description: One of three major mountain ranges in Scotland.

place_825.name: River Thames
place_825.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

place_358.name: Halden
place_358.description: Between 1665 and 1928, known as Fredrikshald. A town and a municipality in Viken County, Norway.

place_434.name: Oslofiord
place_434.description: Fiord of Christiana, now known as Oslofiord, is the stretch of water lying south of Oslo, Norway.

place_364.name: The Sarp Falls
place_364.description: Also known as the Fall(s) of Glommen. The second largest waterfalls by discharge in Europe located on Norway's longest river, the Glomma.

place_1098.name: Heden
place_1098.description: A nature site, near the fall of the Glommen, and Fredrikstad, Norway.

place_217.name: River Danube
place_217.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

place_898.name: Vienna
place_898.description: Austria’s capital, lies in the country’s east on the Danube River.

place_876.name: Lapland
place_876.description: The largest and northernmost region of Finland.

place_1099.name: Fredrikstad
place_1099.description: A city and municipality in Østfold county, Norway.

place_1096.name: Questrin
place_1096.description: Location untraced, but this was on route between Strömstad, Uddevalla, and Gothenburg, during Davy's journey around Sweden in 1824.

place_1101.name: Uddevalla
place_1101.description: A town and the seat of Uddevalla Municipality in Västra Götaland County, Sweden.

place_1102.name: Vänersborg
place_1102.description: A locality and the seat of Vänersborg Municipality, Västra Götaland County, Sweden

place_1104.name: Göta river
place_1104.description: The river leaves Vänern at Vargön, just east of Vänersborg, Sweden; it is a river that drains lake Vänern into the Kattegat, at the city of Gothenburg.

place_362.name: Trollhättan
place_362.description: Trollhattan is a city in Sweden.

place_1107.name: Helsingborg
place_1107.description: A coastal city in southern Sweden, across the Øresund Strait from Denmark.

place_1108.name: Aberdeenshire
place_1108.description: One of the 32 council areas of Scotland.

place_1112.name: Kronborg Slot
place_1112.description: 16th-century castle with banqueting hall & royal chambers, the model for Elsinore in Hamlet.

place_1113.name: fields of Zealand
place_1113.description: The largest and most populous island in Denmark proper.

place_1114.name: Rosenborg Garden
place_1114.description: Next to Rosenborg Palace, the King's Garden is in central Copenhagen.

place_1115.name: Saltholm
place_1115.description: A Danish island in the Øresund, the strait that separates Denmark and Sweden.

place_1116.name: Kiel
place_1116.description: A port city on Germany’s Baltic Sea coast.

place_1117.name: Altona
place_1117.description: The westernmost urban borough(Bezirk) of the German city state of Hamburg.

place_1118.name: Kirchengemeinde Ottensen
place_1118.description: A church in Hamburg, Germany, which contains the grave of the German poet Friedrich Gottlieb Klopstock.

place_1123.name: Holstein
place_1123.description: Holstein is the region between the rivers Elbe and Eider. It is the southern half of Schleswig-Holstein, the northernmost state of Germany.

place_1122.name: Hanover
place_1122.description: The capital and largest city of the German state of Lower Saxony.

place_963.name: Bremen
place_963.description: A city straddling the Weser River in northwest Germany.

place_931.name: Venice
place_931.description: The capital of northern Italy’s Veneto region, Venice is built on more than 100 small islands in a lagoon in the Adriatic Sea.

place_1125.name: Wangerooge
place_1125.description: An island in Germany, one of the East Frisian Islands in the North Sea.

place_688.name: Regensburg
place_688.description: Also known as Ratisbon. Regensberg is a city in Bavaria at the confluence of the Danube, Naab, and Regen rivers.

place_687.name: Linz
place_687.description: Linz is a city in Upper Austria, straddling the Danube River midway between Salzburg and Vienna.

place_1336.name: Pechora River
place_1336.description: the sixth-longest river in Europe. Flowing from Northwest Russia and into the Arctic Ocean, it lies mostly in the Komi Republic but the northernmost part crosses the Nenets Autonomous Okrug.

place_906.name: Caspian sea
place_906.description: The world's largest inland body of water, often described as the world's largest lake or a full-fledged sea.

place_277.name: Innsbruck
place_277.description: Innsbruck is the capital of the Tyrol region of Austria, built on the banks of the Inn River.

place_1129.name: Isen River
place_1129.description: A small river in southeast Upper Bavaria.

place_609.name: River Spey
place_609.description: The River Spey is located in north-east Scotland and is important for both salmon fishing and whisky production.

place_625.name: Vicenza
place_625.description: Vicenza is a city in the north-east of Italy.

place_624.name: Bassano del Grappa
place_624.description: Bassano del Grappa is a city in northern Vicenza region of Italy.

place_619.name: Brenta River
place_619.description: The Brenta River has its source in Trentino, north-east Italy, and flows into the Adriatic. It rises from the lakes Levico and Caldonazzo.

place_085.name: Derbyshire
place_085.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

place_1191.name: Mediterranean Sea
place_1191.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

place_610.name: Brenner Pass
place_610.description: The Brenner Pass is a mountain pass through the Alps that forms the border between Austria and Italy.

place_1132.name: River Corrib
place_1132.description: "The Galway river". In the west of Ireland flows from Lough Corrib through Galway.

place_1136.name: New South Wales
place_1136.description: Today, a state on the east coast of Australia; named in 1770 by Lieutenant James Cook, and founded as a British penal colony in 1788, it originally comprised more than half of the Australian mainland with its western boundary set at 129th meridian east in 1825.

place_1137.name: Palais Royale
place_1137.description: A French royal palace located on Rue Saint-Honoré in the 1st arrondissement of Paris.

place_1138.name: Café des Milles colonnes
place_1138.description: Opened in 1807 at the Palais-Royal palace in Paris in the Montpensier Gallery.

place_685.name: New Holland
place_685.description: New Holland was the name first given to Australia by the Dutch seafarer, Abel Tasman.

place_1140.name: Smolensk
place_1140.description: A city in Russia, occupied by Napoleon during the Battle of Smolensk (1812).

place_1141.name: Troyes
place_1141.description: A commune and the capital of the department of Aube in France.

place_199.name: The Colosseum
place_199.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

place_180.name: Paestum
place_180.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

place_1142.name: Tyrrhenian Sea
place_1142.description: Part of the Mediterranean Sea off the western coast of Italy.

place_179.name: Albulae Aquae
place_179.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

place_182.name: Traun
place_182.description: Traunfall in Desselbrunn, Upper Austria. Memoirs contains a poem Davy wrote about them, also in notebook 14E.

place_184.name: Mount Etna
place_184.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

place_245.name: Ravenna
place_245.description: Ravenna is a city in the north-east of Italy, near the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_272.name: Mondsee
place_272.description: Mondsee is a town in Upper Austria located on the shore of the lake, Mondsee.

place_1146.name: Sankt Goar
place_1146.description: A town in Germany, which Davy visited in 1827.

place_229.name: Bad Aussee
place_229.description: In Styria (Bad Aussee). Bad Aussee is a town in the Austrian state of Styria located at the confluence of the three sources of the Traun River.

place_897.name: France
place_897.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

place_508.name: Land's End
place_508.description: Land's End is a headland on the west coast of Cornwall. It is the most westerly point of mainland England. The underlying rock at Land's End is granite.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_1145.name: Pula
place_1145.description: A seafront city on the tip of Croatia’s Istrian Peninsula.

place_1144.name: Istria
place_1144.description: The largest peninsula within the Adriatic Sea

place_197.name: Salzburg
place_197.description: Salzburg is an Austrian city on the border of Germany, with views of the Eastern Alps.

otherwork_246.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_246.author: Mark Catesby

otherwork_249.author: N. Ozeretskovsky
